tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
"people should play stringed instruments with this song"

tn.ref: cause his face to shine on us
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards them as if Yahweh's face shone a light on them. AT: "act favorably towards us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: your ways may be known on earth
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "people may know your ways on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

The writer desires for everyone to know that God has the power to save them. This can be made clear in the translation. AT: "and the people of all nations may know that you have the power to save them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Let the peoples praise you ... let all the peoples praise you
tn.text: The second clause intensifies the meaning of the first to emphasize the importance of praising God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: let the nations ... govern the nations
tn.text: Here "nations" represents the people who live in all the nations on the earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Let the peoples praise you ... let all the peoples praise you
tn.text: The second clause intensifies the meaning of the first to emphasize how important it is to praise God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: The earth has yielded its harvest
tn.text: Here the writer speaks of "the earth" as if it has chosen to provide a harvest to the people. AT: "We have reaped a bountiful harvest from our crops" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: all the ends of the earth honor him
tn.text: This means that people everywhere should honor God because of his blessings. AT: "I desire that all people everywhere on the earth may have an awesome respect for him" UDB (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
